qas.question: When did Sewall Wright make his suggestion about human populations?
How should populations long inhabiting separate parts of the world be considered?
What is required to allocate individuals in subspecies populations correctly?
What did Wright feel it wouldn't take an anthropologist to easily distinguish between of in groups?
What term is it customary to use instead of subspecies?

context: In <a0_0>1978<a0_0/>, Sewall Wright suggested that human populations that have long inhabited separated parts of the world should, in general, be considered <a1_0>different subspecies<a1_0/> by the usual criterion that most individuals of such populations can be allocated correctly by <a2_0>inspection<a2_0/>. Wright argued that it does not require a trained anthropologist to classify an array of Englishmen, West Africans, and Chinese with 100% accuracy by features, skin color, and type of hair despite so much variability within each of these groups that every <a3_0>individual<a3_0/> can easily be distinguished from every other. However, it is customary to use the term <a4_0>race<a4_0/> rather than subspecies for the major subdivisions of the human species as well as for minor ones.
